Award.AwardTitle: Large Scale Phenomena in Models of Statistical Mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the principal tasks of probability theory is to explain why regularity, or determinism and order, arise at large scales in systems where irregularity, or randomness and disorder, dominate at small scales. This is important for theoretical reasons as it helps validate the use of phenomenological theories whenever small-scale phenomena are not expected to be of relevance, but has also practical consequences as one also needs a recipe for computing various material constants that enter the governing phenomenological equations. The present proposal goes some way towards these goals by analyzing specific systems where large scale phenomena give rise to a new degree of regularity. These systems are of interest for material theory and statistical mechanics in general.

The specific problems proposed to be studied divide into five specific subareas: (1) Random metric structures on the line associated with long-range percolation, (2) Fluctuation theory and homogenization in random resistor networks, (3) Extreme points of the two-dimensional discrete Gaussian Free Field, (4) Stationary Diffusion-Limited Aggregation, (5) Isoperimetric Wulff problems in random environment. A common feature of these problems is that, in the limit when a natural parameter related to size tends to infinity, a limiting structure emerges. This structure can be deterministic, e.g., a limit shape in question (5), or random, e.g., a Poisson process with random fractal intensity measure in question (3) above. The questions to be studied have bearing on several subject areas of probability and statistical mechanics, e.g., disordered systems, growth processes, extreme-order statistics, random geometry. Methods and tools will be borrowed from other parts of mathematics as well, e.g., harmonic analysis, differential equations, homogenization theory and geometric measure theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the early days of modern science, mathematics has been an indispensable tool in formulating, and answering, precise questions arising from physical sciences. This invariably requires the consideration of simplified models that caputure the essential features of the physical systems and yet remain manageable in terms of analysis. The present project carries out this analysis for a number of mathematical models of intrinsic interest. A unifying theme for many of these models is the stochastic interplay of many degrees of freedom which, nonetheless, permits extraction of a so called scaling limit.

The specific problems that have been addressed in the project include extreme-value statistics of logarithmically corelated random fields, random motions in random environments where such extreme values lead to trapping, reduction of distance due to introduction of random edges in spatial graphs, component sizes in growth/aggregation models driven by diffusive motions, asymptotic shapes for large subsets of random graphs that have minimal perimeter for a given volume, similar shape theorems for integer-valued random maps, etc. Precise mathematical objectives are formulated for each of these problems and a solution is presented in the form of a mathematical theorem.


The findings advance the knowledge of current probability theory and its connection with other subjects of mathematics and physical sciences. For instance, the work on logarithmically correlated random fields resolves a number of conjectures made in the physics literature while the work on growth models is an attempt to find a way to formulate the physics conjectures precisely. Other problems simply push the frontier of existing understanding of large systems to a new level. A majority of research performed under the auspices of this award has been done in collaboration with graduate students, postdocs and other junior researchers, thus contributing to workforce training in mathematics and sciences in general.
